simulationTool.authRequest: To access the simulation data, you must first log in to the master portal.
simulationTool.contactInfo: Do you still have questions? Please write an e-mail to
simulationTool.createEnsembleContent: After you have clicked on "Add ensemble" in the ensemble overview, you can create a new ensemble here. Name it as you wish and click on "Create empty ensemble" so that it appears in your ensemble overview and is available for further editing.
simulationTool.createEnsembleContent2: As soon as you click on the plus symbol, you can select the models that your ensemble should contain. Your model selection is displayed in an overview from which you can easily remove models. You can find further settings under the "Configure" function. Click on “Simulate ensemble” to calculate the displayed number of scenarios from the models. These scenarios are displayed in the scenario overview.
simulationTool.createEnsembleContent3: The model-dependent configurations consist on the one hand of the display of the model uncertainties and on the other hand of the settings of the number of scenarios to be calculated and the selection method of the samples from the uncertainty ranges.
simulationTool.createEnsembleHint: Models contain unavoidable mathematical uncertainties that comprise a numerical range instead of a clear numerical value. When an ensemble is simulated, various input parameters from these uncertainty ranges are automatically used to calculate the scenarios.
simulationTool.createScenarioContent: The heart of the Scenario Explorer lies in the execution of simulations. On this page, you can create your own scenario by naming it individually and setting the required input parameters. Click on "Run scenario" to start the calculations and you will be automatically redirected to the scenario detail page.
simulationTool.createScenarioHint: By determining the input parameters, the limiting circumstances under which the respective model is simulated are set. Due to various types of uncertainties, it makes sense to run as many “what-if” scenarios as possible in addition to the “best case”, “worst case” and “business as usual” in order to cover and test a wide range of possible futures that contribute to more robust decision-making.
simulationTool.defaultConfirmText: Are you sure you want to proceed?
simulationTool.ensembleDetailsContent: You can compare the result values within an ensemble using a diagram. You can add further scenarios by clicking on the plus symbol so that the values are included in the diagram for comparison. The scenarios included are displayed by name and color-coded according to their associated model. You can also easily remove scenarios from this overview. You can also share the results of the ensemble with other users by clicking on the share symbol and enter into an exchange with them.
simulationTool.ensembleOverviewContent: This overview lists all ensembles with name, number of scenarios contained, creation date, users who created the scenarios contained in the ensemble, users with whom the ensemble was shared and number of contributions. You can also search, filter and sort your ensembles according to your wishes. Clicking on an ensemble will take you to the ensemble details page where you can edit your ensemble. If you want to create an empty ensemble, you can click on “Add ensemble”.
simulationTool.ensembleOverviewHint: An ensemble consists of a set of different scenarios. This grouping makes it easier to compare results within an ensemble.
simulationTool.landingPageContent: On the start page, you will find quick access to your previous work. There you can search for models, simulations or ensembles by keyword, filter them by parameter or sort them by specific criteria. The preview image shows you which model has been used. The profile picture shows you the users who created the simulation or ensemble. By clicking on the play symbol, you can continue with your work. Below this you will find news to keep you up to date. Here you will be informed about new simulation models that might interest you, new functions of the platform or scenarios or ensembles shared with you.
simulationTool.modelInformationContent: Further information on each model can be found on this detail page. This includes the last update of the model, a comprehensive model description, a list of the required parameters and other model-dependent links.  From this page, you can also start a simulation of the model by clicking on "Simulate" or you have the option of simulating an entire ensemble with one click. What exactly an ensemble is will be explained later in this tutorial.
simulationTool.modelInformationHint: (Simulation) models are tailored to a specific application and can only usefully represent a small part of the complex reality. They include a certain set of parameters in their calculations, which inevitably eliminates others. Different versions of the same model can therefore produce different results. It is therefore important both to check the model used and its purpose to see whether it is suitable for your question and to test several models in order to form a more comprehensive basis for decision-making.
simulationTool.modelOverviewContent: On this page you will find an overview of all currently applicable (simulation) models. If you are looking for specific topics, tags, parameters, model versions, ensemble affiliations, you can search, filter and sort the models accordingly. A clearly laid out setcard provides you with the most important information about the respective model, such as model name, model version, model server and tags. A short description helps you to understand the purpose of the model as quickly as possible. Further details about the respective model can be found under "More information". Alternatively, you can click on the "Simulate" button and start a simulation of the selected model directly.
simulationTool.modelOverviewHint: In contrast to static models, simulations are dynamic models with a progressive index variable, which typically represents time.
simulationTool.name: Name
simulationTool.scenarioDetailsContent: The results of a scenario are displayed graphically on the map. The scenario detail page provides you with the results in writing and using suitable graphs. Here you can see your previously set input parameters in a clear list. The filter function allows you to change the display of the results on the map as you wish. You can enter your own notes for each of your scenarios. You can also share and comment on the scenario with selected users by clicking on the share symbol.
simulationTool.scenarioDetailsHint: Every quantitative result shown here requires an interpretation of the findings in order to ultimately translate the calculated data into a real decision. Every user has their own interests, values and level of knowledge and therefore the results can be interpreted differently. Share your results and engage with other users' points of view.
simulationTool.scenarioOverviewContent:
This overview is a collection of the scenarios you have already created. With the scenario name, the model and ensemble affiliation, the creation date, the user who created the scenario and the users with whom the scenario was shared, you have all the important information at a glance.
The practical search, filter and sort function allows you to quickly find your desired scenario. Click on a scenario of your choice to access the results of the simulation. Wenn du ein neue Simulation erstellen möchtest, klicke auf "Szenario hinzufügen".
simulationTool.scenarioOverviewHint: A scenario is one of several hypothetical consequences of certain events. This results in causal links between causes and effects, whereby the smallest changes in the causes can lead to varying degrees of change in the effects (butterfly effect).
simulationTool.title: Simulations
simulationTool.tutorialInfo: You can find a short tutorial about all important functions here
simulationTool.newsCards: This function will be available soon!
simulationTool.AdigitalSimulation: In contrast to static models, digital simulation models are dynamic and contain a progressive index variable (typically time). Digital simulation models are computer-aided simulations of real or hypothetical systems that make it possible to test, analyze and optimize their behavior under different conditions.
simulationTool.AscenarioJob: A scenario is a hypothetical sequence of possible future developments or conditions based on certain assumptions (parameters).
simulationTool.AEnsemble: An ensemble is a group of different scenarios that are compared with each other in order to examine a wider range of possible future developments. The purpose of an ensemble is to better capture uncertainties and make robust statements about possible futures by examining variability and sensitivity to change.
simulationTool.Aabm: ABM stands for Agent-Based Model. In this simulation method, individual actors (agents) interact with specific rules of behavior in a defined environment. Each agent acts independently and can react to other agents and the environment.
simulationTool.Aiteration: An iteration is a repeated run of a calculation, often with the aim of achieving a more accurate or optimized result.
simulationTool.QgroupEnsemble: How can I group scenarios as an ensemble?
simulationTool.AgroupEnsemble: There are two ways to group your scenarios as an ensemble. On the one hand, you can add your scenarios to the selected ensemble on the ensemble details page or you can create a new ensemble, which generates a set of scenarios by selecting at least one model. Scenarios can then be added to or removed from this ensemble manually.
simulationTool.QdeleteScenario: How can I delete scenarios from the overview?
